review.title: The Structure of Signals: Causal Interdependence Models for Games of Incomplete Information
review.abstract: Traditional economic models typically treat private information, or signals, as generated from some underlying state. Recent work has explicated alternative models, where signals correspond to interpretations of available information. We show that the difference between these formulations can be sharply cast in terms of causal dependence structure, and employ graphical models to illustrate the distinguishing characteristics. The graphical representation supports inferences about signal patterns in the interpreted framework, and suggests how results based on the generated model can be extended to more general situations. Specific insights about bidding games in classical auction mechanisms derive from qualitative graphical models.

metadata.title: The Structure of Signals: Causal Interdependence Models for Games of Incomplete Information

sections.text: Traditional economic models typically treat private information or signals as they are generated by an underlying state. Recent work has shown alternative models in which signals correspond to interpretations of available information. We show that the difference between these formulations can be sharply expressed in terms of the causal dependency structure, and use graphical models to illustrate the different characteristics. Graphical representation supports conclusions about signal patterns in the interpreted framework and suggests how results based on the generated model can be extended to more general situations. Specific insights about bidding games in classic auction mechanisms arise from qualitative graphical models.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In a game of incomplete information, we usually distinguish the information available to each agent in terms of their epistemic types (henceforth only types), and agents are assumed to know their own private types and have probabilistic beliefs about other types of agents. If other types of agents are strategically relevant, our analyses generally look at what agents from their own types can deduce about others, a possibility that only arises when the types are interdependent. Such interdependencies typically arise from the way in which the information of each agent relates to an underlying state of the world. In this case, we can refer to the type of an agent as a signal about that state. Treatment of signals is a central element of theoretical analysis for many classes of multi-agent interactions. Specifically, signals play a central role in formal models of auctions, adjustments, and many other social mechanisms. Canonical theoretical results about these problems take the form of the relationship of properties of signal distributions (e.g., balances) to signal solutions.

sections.heading: 2.1 Bayesian Games
sections.text: In a game of incomplete information, at least some agents do not know some strategically relevant aspects of the game. In order to play or predict the outcome of such a game, it is crucial to model which private information agents have these uncertain aspects. In his groundbreaking work, Harsanyi [1967] used types to capture the private information of agents and defined a game in which the payout functions of agents depend on the types of all agents. It is assumed that each agent knows his own type, but not others. Their beliefs about the types of other agents are given by a probability distribution of possible types of other agents that depend on their own type. Harsanyi called this a Bayesian game. The Bayesian game formulation has since become the standard framework for games of incomplete information. The treatment of types in Bayesian games is useful and elegant, but does not take into account the origins of private information. These types of agents may depend on each other, but the structure of their state may depend on each other.

sections.heading: 2.2 Graphical Models
sections.text: Probabilistic graphical models [Koller and Friedman, 2009, Pearl, 1988] express a distribution over the states of the world bordered by a product range of random variables. The defining feature of such models is their explicit representation of probable dependence in relation to graph structure.2 Formally speaking, a Bayesian network is a commented directed acyclic graph consisting of: 1. Node {X1,.., Xn} representing n random variables, 2. Directed edges between nodes, where Pa (X) denotes the parents of X: nodes with directed edge to X, and 3. A conditional probability function Pr (Xi | Pa (Xi)). 1Everywhere we adopt notation for discrete probability and finite summaries and ask the reader to recognize that the basic concepts of density and integralities are generalizable. 2See the references for comprehensive and in-depth treatments.

sections.heading: 2.3 Example: Interdependent Values in Auction Games
sections.text: To illustrate the use of graphic models to express dependencies in the signal structure, we present Bayesian networks that capture some basic patterns of interdependent values in auction games. Some classic results in auction theory [Krishna, 2010], such as Vickrey's original analysis [Vickrey, 1961], assume independent private values (IPV): that the types of agents (valuations for a good at auction in this environment) are likely to be independent. However, auction theory recognizes that the value of an agent for a good can generally depend on other valuations. For example, the valuation of an expert (e.g. if the good is art or antique furniture) could affect the value of others because it provides evidence of basic common values in authenticity, craftsmanship and other uncertain characteristics of the good. This has direct implications for the bidding strategy in three respects.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: Graphic models provide a language for describing and arguing about the qualitative structure of a decision or game situation, including the private signals on which agents base their decisions. By explicating the signal pattern, we gain insights into the abstract properties of these games. In this paper, we have identified some of these properties that are directly reflected in the graphic structure. In particular, we have shown how the framework of the signals interpreted by Hong and Page can be recast in terms of distinctions about the graphic structure, arguing that this representation facilitates reflection on their implications. Perspective also captures key distinctions in the strategic analysis of prediction markets and auctions. Qualitative models of auction games that extend the independence of Annex A. Structure with monotonicity relationships capture important patterns of reasoning in these domains and suggest generalizations for known outcomes. Graphic models can also be used to solve cases of incomplete information games.
